title: Long ton
text:
Long ton, also known as the imperial ton or displacement ton, is the name for the unit called the "<a href="ton">ton</a>" in the <a href="avoirdupois">avoirdupois</a> system of weights or <a href="Imperial%20unit">Imperial</a> system of measurements. It was standardised in the 13th century. It is used in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> and several other <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a> countries alongside the <a href="mass">mass</a>-based <a href="International%20System%20of%20Units">metric</a> <a href="tonne">tonne</a> defined in 1799, as well as in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> for bulk commodities.
It is not to be confused with the <a href="short%20ton">short ton</a>, a unit of weight equal to used in the United States, and in Canada before <a href="metrication">metrication</a>, also referred to simply as a "ton".
Unit definition.
A long ton is defined as exactly 2,240 pounds. The long ton arises from the traditional British measurement system: A long ton is 20 <a href="hundredweight">hundredweight</a> (cwt), each of which is 8 <a href="Stone%20%28unit%29">stone</a> (1 stone = 14 pounds). Thus a long ton is 20 × 8 × 14 lb = 2,240 lb.

The long ton remains in use in both the United Kingdom and the United States, where it is commonly used in measuring the <a href="Displacement%20%28ship%29">displacement</a> of <a href="ship">ship</a>s, the volume-to-carrying-weight of fuels, and in trade of <a href="wikt%3Abale%23Etymology%203">bale</a>d commodities and bulk goods like <a href="iron%20ore">iron ore</a> and elemental <a href="sulfur">sulfur</a>. The long ton was the unit prescribed for <a href="warship">warship</a>s by the <a href="Washington%20Naval%20Treaty">Washington Naval Treaty</a> of 1922 — for example <a href="battleship">battleship</a>s were limited to a displacement of .
To comply with the practices of the European Union, the British Imperial ton was explicitly excluded from use for trade by the United Kingdom's <a href="Weights%20and%20Measures%20Acts%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Weights and Measures Act</a> of 1985.
The long ton remains in informal use by some heritage rail companies and remains on a limited number of weight limit signs on roads (usually in remote areas away from major towns and cities where <a href="tonne">tonne</a>s are used).
